required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Roles of Almonds in Physical Performance

brief_summary.textblock: Investigators specific aims are to compare the effects of consuming daily snacks of raw, shelled, unsalted almonds (2.0 ounces) versus an isocaloric amount of another commonly consumed snack food (pretzels) on energy (vigor) perception and physical activity, exercise performance (VO2max and measures of strength), strength and power performance as well as muscle soreness recovery after strenuous eccentrically-biased exercise.

detailed_description.textblock: To accomplish these aims, investigators will examine whether regular consumption of almonds versus a common snack food over a period of 8 weeks impacts longer term metabolic, physiological and behavioral responses related to energy sensations and exercise capacity/performance.

primary_outcome.measure: Changes from baseline in energy (vigor) perception
primary_outcome.description: Energy (vigor) perception will be assessed using POMS questionnaire

primary_outcome.measure: Changes from baseline in exercise performance
primary_outcome.description: VO2max will be assessed for measuring exercise performance

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes from baseline in strength and power performance
secondary_outcome.description: strength and power performance by be measure by biodex

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes from baseline in muscle soreness
secondary_outcome.description: muscle soreness will be measured by DOMES questionnaire

arm_group.description: Participants will consume 2.0 oz of raw, shelled, unsalted almonds.
an isocaloric (2.0 oz raw almonds) amount of unsalted pretzels daily.

intervention.description: 2.0 oz of raw, shelled, unsalted almonds
an isocaloric amount of unsalted pretzels

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 30-50 years old
- BMI of 23-30
Exclusion Criteria:
- smoking,
- medications known to impact inflammation,
- musculoskeletal limitations and
- use of supplements within 1 month of participation that are known to impact antioxidant
- use of supplements within 1 month of participation that are known to impact inflammatory status
